Graphical abstract







Highlights



•
A MOF is changed into another one by soaking in methanol.


•
Both extended structures consist of two interpenetrating MOFs.


•
Both structures are featured with 12-connected Co5 clusters as the nodes.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0050">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A MOF is changed into another one by soaking in methanol.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Both extended structures consist of two interpenetrating MOFs.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Both structures are featured with 12-connected Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> clusters as the nodes.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st090">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">A novel Co(II)-based metal–organic framework, namely {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (BTE)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; BTE<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′,4″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyltris-(ethyne-2,1-diyl))tribenzoate) was obtained by solvothermal synthesis and structurally determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, TG–DSC analysis, elemental analysis and IR spectroscopy. After soaked in methanol, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was turned into another compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, namely {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (BTE)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}, through single crystal-to-single crystal transform. These two structures are featured with some 12-connected Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> nodes which are bridged by tripod BTE ligands into the interpenetrating frameworks. The gas sorption behaviors were examined.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
A MOF is changed into another one by soaking in methanol.
Both extended structures consist of two interpenetrating MOFs.
Both structures are featured with 12-connected Co5 clusters as the nodes.
Abstract
A novel Co(II)-based metal–organic framework, namely {[Co5(OH)(H2O)(DMF)4] (BTE)3} (1; BTE=4,4′,4″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyltris-(ethyne-2,1-diyl))tribenzoate) was obtained by solvothermal synthesis and structurally determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, TG–DSC analysis, elemental analysis and IR spectroscopy. After soaked in methanol, 1 was turned into another compound 2, namely {[Co5(OH)(H2O)2(CH3OH)4] (BTE)3}, through single crystal-to-single crystal transform. These two structures are featured with some 12-connected Co5 nodes which are bridged by tripod BTE ligands into the interpenetrating frameworks. The gas sorption behaviors were examined.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increasing attention due to their intriguing architectures and potential applications in the areas of gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, nonlinear optics, magnetism and so on . Much effort has been devoted to the construction of MOFs with tunable properties using metal clusters as secondary building units (SBUs) and organic ligands as linkers . Compared with the way to rationalize novel network topologies and improve the properties by designing the linkers, it is a rather complex process to build MOFs with in situ generated polynuclear units as SBUs . The creation of anticipated cluster, especially high-connected cluster SBUs, is still a challenge. Some compounds based on polynuclear Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2–8) clusters and multicarboxylate have been reported . Dietzel et al. reported a MOF compound with 1D pores containing some Co(II) chains as infinite-rod SBUS and 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate as the linker . Recently, Han and co-workers prepared two 6-connected 3D frameworks with Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> or Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> cluster SBUs .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increasing attention due to their intriguing architectures and potential applications in the areas of gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, nonlinear optics, magnetism and so on . Much effort has been devoted to the construction of MOFs with tunable properties using metal clusters as secondary building units (SBUs) and organic ligands as linkers . Compared with the way to rationalize novel network topologies and improve the properties by designing the linkers, it is a rather complex process to build MOFs with in situ generated polynuclear units as SBUs . The creation of anticipated cluster, especially high-connected cluster SBUs, is still a challenge. Some compounds based on polynuclear CoII

n
 (n
=2–8) clusters and multicarboxylate have been reported . Dietzel et al. reported a MOF compound with 1D pores containing some Co(II) chains as infinite-rod SBUS and 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate as the linker . Recently, Han and co-workers prepared two 6-connected 3D frameworks with Co5 or Co2 cluster SBUs .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Here we present two novel MOFs based on the pentanuclear Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> clusters as the nodes and 4,4′,4″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyltris-(ethyne-2,1-diyl))tribenzoate (BTE<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>) as the linker. More precisely, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> we obtained one by solvothermal synthesis and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained by soaking <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in methanol to replace the bonded/adsorbed DMF solvent with methanol. Both structures consist of two interpenetrated 3D metal–organic frameworks. It should be noted that all the Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> clusters exhibit a rarely reported 12-connected coordination mode while the Co sites in these two structures show different coordination modes. The gas sorption of the extended structure was investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Here we present two novel MOFs based on the pentanuclear Co5 clusters as the nodes and 4,4′,4″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyltris-(ethyne-2,1-diyl))tribenzoate (BTE3−) as the linker. More precisely, compound 1 we obtained one by solvothermal synthesis and compound 2 was obtained by soaking 1 in methanol to replace the bonded/adsorbed DMF solvent with methanol. Both structures consist of two interpenetrated 3D metal–organic frameworks. It should be noted that all the Co5 clusters exhibit a rarely reported 12-connected coordination mode while the Co sites in these two structures show different coordination modes. The gas sorption of the extended structure was investigated.

other properties: Co5 clusters exhibit a rarely reported 12-connected coordination mode

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Materials and measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">All the reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. TG–DSC measurement was performed on a PYRIS DIAMOND from room temperature to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> under atmosphere. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a Bruker Vertex 70 spectrometer. Elemental analysis for C, H, N was recorded on a VarioEL instrument. N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption measurement for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M automatic volumetric instrument.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section
Materials and measurements
All the reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. TG–DSC measurement was performed on a PYRIS DIAMOND from room temperature to 800°C, with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 under atmosphere. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a Bruker Vertex 70 spectrometer. Elemental analysis for C, H, N was recorded on a VarioEL instrument. N2 adsorption measurement for 1 was performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020M automatic volumetric instrument.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st020">Preparation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTE (0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NOH (25% in water, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml), DMF (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) were placed in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml Teflon-lined autoclave which was kept at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days and then slowly cooled to room temperature at about 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h. Purple block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained. Elemental analysis: calculated (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">111</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">76</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf> without the solvent molecules: C 62.11, H 3.54, N 2.61; found (%): C 64.40, H 5.96, N 2.35. The discrepancy would be due to the involved solvent molecules in the lattices. FT-IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3423(br), 2961(m), 2930(m), 2865(m), 1675(s), 1606(s), 1547(w), 1492(s), 1287(w), 1260(s), 1135(m), 1081(s), 840(m).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of 1 and 2


1: CoCl2·6H2O (0.1g, 0.4mmol), H3BTE (0.05g, 0.1mmol), (CH3)4NOH (25% in water, 0.5ml), DMF (4ml) and CH3OH (4ml) were placed in a 20ml Teflon-lined autoclave which was kept at 130°C for 3days and then slowly cooled to room temperature at about 4°C/h. Purple block crystals of 1 were obtained. Elemental analysis: calculated (%) for C111H76Co5N4O24 without the solvent molecules: C 62.11, H 3.54, N 2.61; found (%): C 64.40, H 5.96, N 2.35. The discrepancy would be due to the involved solvent molecules in the lattices. FT-IR (cm−1): 3423(br), 2961(m), 2930(m), 2865(m), 1675(s), 1606(s), 1547(w), 1492(s), 1287(w), 1260(s), 1135(m), 1081(s), 840(m).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">
<ce:bold>2:</ce:bold> The crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained by soaking <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in methanol due to the solvent exchanged.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st025">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The intensity data were recorded on a Bruker APEX CCD system with Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The diffraction data were treated by the “SQUEEZE” method as implemented in PLATON  to remove diffuse electron density associated with the disordered solvent molecules. The crystal structures were solved by means of Direct Methods and refined employing full-matrix least squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (SHELXTL-97) . Crystal data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">111</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">76</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2144.41<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g/mol, monoclinic, <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>a<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>25.056(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>36.884(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>19.669(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>β<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>123.272(2)°, <ce:italic>V<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15198(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

</ce:italic>0.585<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>T<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

Crystal data for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: C<ce:inf loc="post">103</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">66</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">25</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

</ce:italic>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>)], GooF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.000. All the non-hydrogen atoms except a water oxygen atom and a DMF molecule were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
2: The crystals of 2 were obtained by soaking 1 in methanol due to the solvent exchanged.
X-ray crystallography
The intensity data were recorded on a Bruker APEX CCD system with Mo Kα radiation (λ
=0.71073Å). The diffraction data were treated by the “SQUEEZE” method as implemented in PLATON  to remove diffuse electron density associated with the disordered solvent molecules. The crystal structures were solved by means of Direct Methods and refined employing full-matrix least squares on F

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st030">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Crystal structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in a monoclinic system with space group <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic>. There are three different crystallographic Co sites (namely, Co1–Co3) which are all six-coordinated. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, Co1 site is coordinated by four carboxylate groups, one DMF molecule and one OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Co2 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three different carboxylate groups, one DMF molecule and one OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Co3 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different BTE molecules, two DMF molecules and two OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O entities. Five adjacent cobalt atoms are bridged by two OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O entities and the carboxylate oxygen atoms into a pentanuclear Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster which is interconnected with 12 others by 9 BTE molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). When viewed in the polyhedral mode, the Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster can be thought to be constructed by three edge-sharing CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra (in cyan) and two hanged octahedra (in yellow<ce:footnote id="fn1">
<ce:label>1</ce:label>
<ce:note-para id="np005" view="all">For interpretation of color in Fig. 1, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote>
, ). The Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster acts as a 12-connected node and the BTE molecule acts as a linker. And then a 3D extended structure forms (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). It is found that the extended structure consists of two interpenetrating MOFs. When viewed along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, the structure exhibits some small channels.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Crystal structures of 1 and 2

Compound 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic system with space group C2/c. There are three different crystallographic Co sites (namely, Co1–Co3) which are all six-coordinated. As shown in 
, Co1 site is coordinated by four carboxylate groups, one DMF molecule and one OH−/H2O. Co2 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three different carboxylate groups, one DMF molecule and one OH−/H2O. Co3 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different BTE molecules, two DMF molecules and two OH−/H2O entities. Five adjacent cobalt atoms are bridged by two OH−/H2O entities and the carboxylate oxygen atoms into a pentanuclear Co5 cluster which is interconnected with 12 others by 9 BTE molecules (
). When viewed in the polyhedral mode, the Co5 cluster can be thought to be constructed by three edge-sharing CoO6 octahedra (in cyan) and two hanged octahedra (in yellow
1
For interpretation of color in Fig. 1, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.

, ). The Co5 cluster acts as a 12-connected node and the BTE molecule acts as a linker. And then a 3D extended structure forms (

). It is found that the extended structure consists of two interpenetrating MOFs. When viewed along the c axis, the structure exhibits some small channels.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained by soaking <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in methanol with the bonded solvent DMF replaced by methanol molecules. Compared with the extended structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the net of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> keeps unchanged, that is, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is also featured two interpenetrating MOFs with the 12-connected Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> clusters as the nodes and 3-connected BTE molecules as the linkers. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also crystallizes in a monoclinic system. However, the space group is changed from <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and the formation of the Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster is also changed. Different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, there are five different crystallographic Co sites (namely, Co1–Co5). The sites Co1, Co2 and Co4 are six-coordinated, Co3 is four-coordinated and Co5 is seven-coordinated. Co1 site is coordinated by two carboxylate groups, two methanol molecules and two OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Co2 or Co4 is coordinated by four carboxylate groups, one methanol and one OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Co3 is coordinated by three carboxylate groups and one OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O entity. Co5 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three different BTE molecules and three OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O entities. Five adjacent cobalt atoms are also bridged by the OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O entities and the carboxylate groups into a pentanuclear Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster. Different from those in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster consists of two edge-sharing CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>/CoO<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> polyhedra and three vertex-sharing CoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>/CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>/CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> polyhedra ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Compound 2 was obtained by soaking 1 in methanol with the bonded solvent DMF replaced by methanol molecules. Compared with the extended structure of 1, the net of 2 keeps unchanged, that is, 2 is also featured two interpenetrating MOFs with the 12-connected Co5 clusters as the nodes and 3-connected BTE molecules as the linkers. 2 also crystallizes in a monoclinic system. However, the space group is changed from C2/c in 1 to P21
/c in 2 and the formation of the Co5 cluster is also changed. Different from 1, there are five different crystallographic Co sites (namely, Co1–Co5). The sites Co1, Co2 and Co4 are six-coordinated, Co3 is four-coordinated and Co5 is seven-coordinated. Co1 site is coordinated by two carboxylate groups, two methanol molecules and two OH−/H2O. Co2 or Co4 is coordinated by four carboxylate groups, one methanol and one OH−/H2O. Co3 is coordinated by three carboxylate groups and one OH−/H2O entity. Co5 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three different BTE molecules and three OH−/H2O entities. Five adjacent cobalt atoms are also bridged by the OH−/H2O entities and the carboxylate groups into a pentanuclear Co5 cluster. Different from those in 1, the Co5 cluster consists of two edge-sharing CoO6/CoO7 polyhedra and three vertex-sharing CoO4/CoO6/CoO6 polyhedra ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st040">TG measurement</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Thermal gravimetric (TG) curves of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits two-step weight loss below 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). The weight loss from room temperature to about 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be assigned to the release of all coordinated water, DMF molecules and lattice solvent molecules. The second weight loss from 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the decomposition of the compound, which is indicated by an exothermal peak at 413<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DSC curve. The residue value is of 20% due to the formation of CoO. Later, the weight increases a little with the increasing temperature, which might be caused by the oxidation of the CoO intermediate product.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st045">Gas sorption of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The porosities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were evaluated by measuring N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Before the gas sorption measurement, the samples of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were vacuum dried at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>) exhibits a type-I adsorption behavior, which suggests that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possess permanent porosity. From the adsorption branch of the isotherm, the Langmuir and BET surface areas were calculated to be 347.6 and 267.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. A whole hysteresis of desorption was observed in the isotherm. The sample also exhibits some gas adsorption toward H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. A similar hysteresis of desorption was also observed in the isotherm of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Gas sorption of 2

The porosities of compounds 1 and 2 were evaluated by measuring N2 sorption at 77K. Before the gas sorption measurement, the samples of 2 were vacuum dried at 100°C. The N2 adsorption isotherm (
) exhibits a type-I adsorption behavior, which suggests that 1 and 2 possess permanent porosity. From the adsorption branch of the isotherm, the Langmuir and BET surface areas were calculated to be 347.6 and 267.7m2
g−1, respectively. A whole hysteresis of desorption was observed in the isotherm. The sample also exhibits some gas adsorption toward H2. A similar hysteresis of desorption was also observed in the isotherm of H2.

other properties: N2 adsorption isotherm exhibits type-I adsorption behavior
Hysteresis of desorption observed in the isotherm
Some gas adsorption toward H2 observed
Hysteresis of desorption observed in the isotherm of H2

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st050">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In conclusion, a cobalt-organic compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> featured with interpenetrating MOFs and 12-connected Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster nodes was obtained by solvothermal synthesis. By soaking <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in methanol, another compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained through single crystal-to-single crystal transform. Interesting, the network of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was nearly kept unchanged but the space group of the crystal structure was changed from <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The gas sorption measurements indicated permanent porosity in the extended structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In conclusion, a cobalt-organic compound 1 featured with interpenetrating MOFs and 12-connected Co5 cluster nodes was obtained by solvothermal synthesis. By soaking 1 in methanol, another compound 2 was obtained through single crystal-to-single crystal transform. Interesting, the network of 1 was nearly kept unchanged but the space group of the crystal structure was changed from C2/c in 1 to P21
/c in 2. The gas sorption measurements indicated permanent porosity in the extended structures.

other properties: permanent porosity in the extended structures

metadata.title: Two interpenetrating 3D frameworks based on 12-connected pentanuclear Co5 clusters
